Protest vote. This should not be considered a board game. It's more akin to something like traditional darts.
I don't get flicking at all - my fingers start to hurt within minutes. Not into torture games lol.
strictly a me problem
Just found it boring… Others love it, but wasn’t for me…
It is fun, but it is not a table top game.
Never understood the craziness around Crokinole. There are a lot of better flicking games. I will never play it again
Dexterity games = I hate (I think pitch car is the one exception).
I don't have the flicking gene so too frustrating to play again.
Flat "marbles" on a wooden plate . . . what's all the fuss? Extremely overrated.
I hate this highly-overrated game. Besides, do you ever notice when you hit a rail (whatever they're called) that your fingernail hurts more?
It just fell flat for me.
A flicking game from the past, that should better remain there.
I get it , classic , old, dexterity . I'd rather play Pitch Car and have some silly fun.

1 Play

Would play carrom over this. I guess I can tolerate this once in a while for a quick game though.

Crokinole

Only two rounds played on a supposedly really good board but disliked it. It's finicky getting the power of the flick right and wasn't particularly exciting or interesting - just a flicking game on a smooth board and I'm bad at it, bad at measuring power and not good at angling my shots. It just was rather meh and surprised me how praised it is. Then again I dislike dexterity games in general.

2.5/10
It's shuffleboard with finger flicking wooden pieces. Why is it a Top 50 game here at BGG???
Woefully limited and pedestrian in comparison to the far superior game Carrom.

Not a game.

Sport or toy, yes. Game, no.
I don't really understand the hype. Really hard.

2024.
Alright dexterity game. I see why people might like it, but if you suck at it (like me) it gets boring quickly.

Rated after fewer than 3 plays.
This is pickleball to Carrom's Tennis.

2025-02-20
BGG rating after first play, 2p, on a nice, big wooden version: 4/10.
Not a boardgame, but a dexterity game. I'm not a big fan of games like this, hockey or soccer games, darts etc., but it's an ok casual activity. It beats playing trivia games.
The weird thing about this game, is that it's actually more fun the worse you are at it. Seeing expert players play is boring as hell, but as an amateur is a fun light flicking game.
Played someone else's, it was just ok. Not up to the hype for me.
it's not a "bad" game - rating would be higher if it had its own category.
Would make for a great parlor game. But I'm not clamoring to play this at a game day.

4/5

canadian shuffleboard. classic game. expensive and takes up a lot of space. there are cheaper and smaller dexterity games now.

good disc-flicking game
A real wooden board is very expensive!
It's not for me. I don't have the patience. Average score.
I'm really terrible at it, but it's beautiful to behold and plays in a short time.

This one ($88 with tax): https://www.amazon.com/dp/B093HHM9PY?ref_=ppx_hzsearch_conn_...

As a kid, one of my friend's family had a home-made crokinole board with pencil-erasers for the center bumper posts. I'm pretty sure we were playing the rules wrong too, because we usually only tried to knock the other's pieces off the board in the fastest and hardest way possible... Seems like if I played it now it might be a pretty fun dexterity game, but I still don't understand the rules to be honest.
Easy sit and relaxing.
Everyone needs one of these right?

Clearly I'm not the audience here. I like many dexterity games, but this one is just not particularly interesting to me. It's too austere, so I guess I prefer to zaniness of several other entries into the dexterity genre.

Also seems like part of the appeal involves a collector's mentality and the craftsmanship of the boards themselves. I can understand this appeal, but don't share it.
This is an average dexterity game. It's only interesting because it's large and expensive. However, those two factors make it rather unreasonable to actually own.

Very basic game of flicking and trying to outmanuver your opponent, great simple ruleset that demands you play with skill, but rewards good strategy and clever play.

Brilliant high 5ing moments when someone pulls off an awesome shot too.

Can see why this has stood the test of time.

Pros:
-Amazingly simple
-Some strategy / flicking methods to master
-Approachable to anyone

Cons:
-Can get tiresome after several rounds in a row
-No joke: long sessions can lead to bruising of the fingers
-More of a "background game"

Crokinole is an absolute classic. I find that this game is best suited to be a background game, played while drinking or having deep conversations with friends. While fun, playing too many games in a session can quickly get a little boring. I think this is a great game to play for a half hour, at the beginning of a game night to ease into something heavier.
Not really a boardgame, but fun to play

Mayday Maple version with more disks, carrying bag and rubber hose kit. Shut Up and Sit Down made me buy this.

Ended up being so-so and never really took hold in my family.

6/23/22: sold
I have poor dexterity so I'm awful at this game.
So the canadians voting "en masse" to keep this game up in the list. WTF??? If you prefer classic entertainment, Chess would be number 1 and kickin' other asses, for sure.
Backgammon-ey aesthetic. About commanding the inner circle. Flicking technique matters a lot and then it's about corner cases. Probably clever for its time.

Played for the first time at The Treehouse Board Game Cafe in Sheffield, UK. rules seem simple and there are some strange wordings, game is basically aim for the center but if there is another color you have to aim for it.
Played in 2018
It's a neat dexterity game I play with my wife's family. It's fun and hard to play well.
Another one of those lifestyle games that I'm super happy to own but would never recommend someone go out of their way to acquire (or play!).

I don't understand why this is BGG's dexterity game of choice and why it gets anointed as good while most other dexterity games get downgraded as gimmicky. Rating this so highly kind of feels like rating family favorites like Hearts or Euchre in the top 100, something that's very anathema to BGG.

That said, it's a good dexterity game. There's enough disks that you'll probably make one or two shots you feel really good about, and there will also be a shot or two where you want to hit yourself because you flubbed it so bad. It's very accessible.

One of the better dexterity games out there. It's perfect for playing after a long day and not wanting anything too heavy to think about/figure out. Scoring is a little different but it's always a good time.

My grandfather was master of this game - I never beat him. I love the spatial aspect (i.e. using pegs as defense), but sometimes the flicking hurts my fingers 
Board was too old (edges were actually falling apart), so no longer own.
Top 100 Poster #70

This is rated highly because its the only parlour game on BGG. I'd rather play billiards, darts, shuffleboard, or any of the other options over this. Heck, ladder ball and bean bags / corn hole are better dexterity games.
Very limited of what this game is. Expensive, lot of space, but it gives only dexternity based play, when occupying so much space. Not worth it.

I bought a new peg and covering. We played and enjoyed it.
KS
It's fine. But this is 300% a different category than board games. I like shuffle board too, but wouldn't put it on this list.

Think of it as the granddaddy of shuffleboard and air hockey. Super simple to learn but tricky to master, especially after a couple of drinks. It’s all fun and games until someone scores a 20 and the table gets competitive. Perfect for a laid-back night with friends.

Every time I play Crokinole is such a treat. It's one of my favorite games to show people, seeing how the table goes from bewilderment at this giant, wooden circle to cautious optimism after their first flick to raucous cheering and laughter all in the space of about 10 minutes. And then it stays raucous for hours! Games like Crokinole are why I love this hobby.
Fun in small amounts, but frustrating when you keep missing. One might find it too big and pricey for the - very replayable but still - small game it is.
Fun. Interesting and short.

A classic and solid dexterity game. Depth comes from strategy and not any mechanisms in the game, which shows its age a bit. Must have a good board to truly enjoy. But quick enough to always hit the table.
Classic dexterity game
Finally tried this at GenCon. I can see the fun of the dexterity aspect for some people but it was weirdly hard for me and I think I prefer games like curling or pluck.
Great game of dexterity and tactics.
Good for calm evenings
fun slidey game

It’s a smart and funny dexterity game.

Addictive dexterity game! I hope my girlfriend will like it more!

Crokinole is a very fun "skill and action" sort of game.
It is best for 2 or 4 players. Just like pool or darts, this is a game where you build muscle-memory skill. Making difficult shots is very rewarding.

Easily my favorite "dexterity" game. But more than just that, easily one of my favorite games.

I own a custom board, decorated with my Game Bistro logo, and signed on the back by all the regulars of my old game night. This is a treasured possession.

2 player; 4 player
Addicting. Organically creates interesting situations from a relatively simple ruleset. Main issue I have with it are that the open 20 shot is too important for the game.
Should it be classified as a "board" game? Not sure. However, it's damn fun.
Amazing 2 or 4 player game. Goes great with drinks 10/10. Downside takes a lot of space.

Who knew that a 200 year old Canadian circle would be so damn fun?? And it's a gorgeous wall piece to boot. Can't believe I ignored this game for so long… it captures the heart of every single person who tries it.
I have a tremor and poor control of my hands, but crokinole is too fun not to even try

Comments entered on 03 Apr 2010:

Crokinole is a dexterity game that plays very quickly. Despite the simplicity of components and rules, the game has a depth to it that is related to the ability of the player to flick their discs effectively.

I had never played this game before working at Fantasy Flight Games. James Torr had a board that he brought to work and for quite a while it was the lunch time game to play.

In February 2010, I pre-ordered a board from Mayday Games but I am still awaiting its arrival. I look forward to playing this game actively again.

Comments entered on 04 Sep 2010:

I received the board from Mayday Games yesterday. Very nice and will begin increasing the number of plays significantly.
perfection
So much fun

This seems out of place for a board game site, it's more of a pub game/sport, and it's more accessible than any board game and usually more fun. People who don't enjoy board games will likely enjoy it, and many board gamers don't enjoy it either, so its inclusion on BGG seems misplaced. If I had to either get rid of all my board games or get rid of my crokinole board, I would keep the board and dump the games.
Only minus? Price

Price can be a real turnover, as well as its huge size, but if you take the plunge you won't regret it.

Super accessible, easy rules, playable by all ages, instant fun, quick plays, lot of laughs or "Ooooh" moments.

Fantastic game ; glad that I discovered it and bought one.

Walnut + Black Leathered Crokinole from Masters Traditional Games / Woodestic.
just a great, addictive, family game. we all love it.
Eternal Canadian classic!

Top 3 for most played physical game alongside Crib and Chess. My grandparents had a board they stored under their couch and we pulled it out whenever we went there.

Super nostalgic game for me. Fortunate to have been gifted a board by my parents and I can't wait to play it with my son when he gets older.
